Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will conduct comprehensive surveys and inventories of amphibians and reptiles throughout Haiti -- in areas of known diversity, as well as in poorly known and unexplored regions. The primary goals are to determine how much of the known diversity of species still exists, and how much remains undescribed. Haiti is one of the poorest countries in the world and its land surface is now essentially devoid of native vegetation because of human activities. Some of the once-rich biodiversity of the country can be found in small, isolated patches of forest, but these forest remnants are largely unprotected, threatening the survival of nearly all species.

Although Haiti shares the island of Hispaniola with the Dominican Republic, a large number of species occur only in Haiti. It has the highest proportion of threatened amphibian species of any country in the world. Many new species are likely to be discovered during this project. Sampling and analytical methods used during the inventories will provide critical data for understanding the process of mass extinction, to inform conservation management decisions, and to help prevent loss of biodiversity elsewhere. The project also involves training of graduate and undergraduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The amphibians and reptiles of Haiti were surveyed to determine the distribution and composition of species. Haiti is unusual in that it has lost nearly all (99%) of its original forests, leaving pockets of forest and biodiversity primarily in areas difficult to access, such as mountain tops. During eight expeditions, 105 species of amphibians and reptiles were encountered, including 27 species new to science, which will greatly increase the known fauna of Haiti. This suggests that species diversity in other groups is likely underestimated as well. Therefore, Haiti's biodiversity crisis would appear to be more serious than previously thought. Observing the changes that occur during a major loss of biodiversity will be important for understanding how to mitigate such declines there and elsewhere. The results are described in journal articles and reports. Graduate and undergraduate students have participated in the surveys, which have engaged Haitian collaborators and students.

Working together with a Haitian non-governmental conservation agency, the Audubon Society of Haiti, the project has raised awareness of the decline in Haiti's biodiversity.  A multiligual web site, www.caribnature.org, was developed for web video essays that show biodiversity on mountain tops and discuss reasons for the loss of species. A multiligual biodiversity calendar for 2013 was designed by the project and distributed throughout Haiti by the Audubon Society of Haiti, and a documentary was produced, detailing the research and conservation work. The government of Haiti was informed and engaged throughout the project.
